trial_identification.studytitle: Effect of Nurse-run Walk-in Clinic on Emergency Department workload
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Emergency Department patient workload following introduction of Nurse-run Walk-in Clinic in a Tertiary Hospital

interventions.interventions: Walk in Clinic opening on hospital campus May 2010: Nurse run service seeing and treating self referred ambulatory patients independentt of other hospital services. Effects will be observed over 12 months
interventions.comparator: Changes in Emergency Department workload following the opening of the new Walk-in Clinic. Comparison of 12 months data with previous 5 years (Jan 2005-May 2010). The walk-in clinic is a new free service, one aim of which is to reduce demand on the Emergency Department. At this time there are no planned changes to the Emergency Department itself.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Emergency Medicine presentations: number, triage, outcome, time of presentation, referral source and disposition based on hospital electronic records (multiple different systems)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 6 and 12 months post new clinic opening

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Emergency Medicine Outcomes/Disposition/Diagnosis using hospital databases and electronic records
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: 6 and 12 months post new clinic opening

fundingsource.fundingaddress: ANU Medical School The Canberra Hospital Yamba Dr Garran ACT 2605

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Primary purpose is to assess the effect of the hospital based walk-in clinic on hospital Emergency Department workload

ethicscommitee.ethicaddress: ACT Health Research Office Building 10, Level 6 Canberra Hospital Yamba Drive, Garran Canberra, ACT 2605
